posts.cooked: My team was wanting to use this Electric Linear Actuator from Amazon and was wondering if this would be legal?

link_counts.title: 3 Inch 4.5lbs Mini Stroke 12V 4.5lbs Electric Linear Actuator 1.2"/sec Linear Motion Actuator with Brackets for Cabinets, Robotics, Home Automation, Window Opener(20N, 75mm): Amazon.com: Industrial & Scientific

posts.name: David B
posts.cooked: I am inclined to say no since it has a motor to activate the linear actuator and the motor listed on the spec sheet is not on the list of approved motors. However if you modified the actuator to use a motor on the approved list it would them become legal.

posts.name: Domtech
posts.cooked:
It is allowed, the rules were changed in the last few years to allow COTS linear actuators without replacing the motors.

There is a catch though, if you look at the last row of the table of allowed actuators in rule R501, it specifies that they must be used with a 20 amp breaker or smaller.

For this tiny actuator it shouldn’t be an issue. Also, you should be aware that these are usually weaker than you would expect.

posts.name: Eric Tate
posts.cooked: Yes - allowed per thr game manual but you may want to consider a 6V Linear Servo which is very similar but can be controlled to specific posostion using a PWM signal. AndyMark part number am-3517 for example.

posts.name: David B
posts.cooked: Whoops my age was showing, only 4 Cims anyone?

posts.name: Ada T
posts.cooked: I bet a team has made linear actuation with 4 cims in the past few years

posts.name: David B
posts.cooked: I was trying to reference the years of old when you could only have four cims on your robot total.

posts.name: Ada T
posts.cooked: I know, I meant a team using 4 cims just for a linear actuator
